abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>
                  <jats:italic>Gracilaria mammillaris</jats:italic> has been the most common flattened <jats:italic>Gracilaria</jats:italic> reported from North Carolina offshore waters. Analyses of <jats:italic>rbc</jats:italic>L sequences from North Carolina specimens identified as <jats:italic>G. mammillaris</jats:italic> revealed that they were actually <jats:italic>Gracilaria galatensis</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>Gracilaria hayi</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>Gracilaria isabellana</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>Gracilaria occidentalis</jats:italic>. Comparisons of contemporary <jats:italic>Gracilaria rbc</jats:italic>L sequences with a partial sequence from the <jats:italic>G. mammillaris</jats:italic> holotype indicated that <jats:italic>G. mammillaris</jats:italic> is most likely not present in North Carolina. Specimens from Venezuela and Brazil originally identified as <jats:italic>Gracilaria curtissiae</jats:italic> are <jats:italic>G. mammillaris</jats:italic>, and the currently designated <jats:italic>G. mammillaris</jats:italic> epitype represents a unique species described here as <jats:italic>Gracilaria gurgelii</jats:italic> sp. nov.</jats:p>
title: Studies of North Carolina marine algae XIV: increased diversity of flattened offshore Gracilaria (Gracilariales, Rhodophyta) species revealed by DNA sequences of contemporary specimens and the G. mammillaris holotype
